articles.title: Physicists close in on the elusive sterile neutrino
articles.summary: Neutrinos may be nearly invisible, but they play a starring role in the Universe. Long-standing anomalies had hinted at a mysterious fourth “sterile” neutrino, potentially rewriting the laws of physics. Using exquisitely precise measurements of tritium decay, the KATRIN experiment found no evidence for such a particle, sharply contradicting earlier claims. With more data and upgrades ahead, the hunt is far from over.
articles.content:
Neutrinos are extraordinarily difficult to detect, yet they are among the most abundant matter particles in the Universe. According to the Standard Model of particle physics, there are three known kinds. That picture changed when scientists discovered neutrino oscillations, a phenomenon showing that neutrinos have mass and can switch between types as they move through space. Over the years, several unexplained experimental results have fueled speculation about a fourth variety known as a sterile neutrino, which would interact even more weakly than the others. Confirming its existence would mark a major shift in our understanding of fundamental physics.

A new study published in Nature reports the most precise direct search so far for sterile neutrinos. The work comes from the KATRIN collaboration, which analyzed radioactive decays of tritium to look for subtle signs of an additional neutrino type.

The KATRIN (Karlsruhe Tritium Neutrino) experiment was originally designed to measure the mass of neutrinos. It does this by carefully tracking the energies of electrons released during the β-decay of tritium. When tritium decays, the neutrino carries away some energy, which slightly alters the energy pattern of the emitted electrons. If a sterile neutrino were sometimes produced instead, it would leave a recognizable distortion, or "kink," in that pattern.

Located at the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology in Germany, KATRIN stretches more than 70 meters in length. Its setup includes a powerful windowless gaseous tritium source, a high-resolution spectrometer that precisely measures electron energies, and a detector that records the particles. Since beginning operations in 2019, the experiment has collected tritium β-decay data with unmatched precision, specifically searching for the tiny deviations expected from a sterile neutrino.

What the Data Reveal About Sterile Neutrinos

In the new Nature paper, the team reports the most sensitive tritium β-decay search for sterile neutrinos to date. Between 2019 and 2021, KATRIN recorded about 36 million electrons over 259 days of data taking. These measurements were compared with detailed models of β-decay and achieved accuracy better than one percent. The analysis found no evidence of a sterile neutrino.

This result rules out a broad range of possibilities that had been suggested by earlier anomalies. Those anomalies included unexpected deficits seen in reactor-neutrino experiments and gallium-source measurements, both of which had hinted at a fourth neutrino. The findings also completely contradict the Neutrino-4 experiment, which had claimed evidence for such a particle.

KATRIN's exceptionally low background means that nearly all detected electrons originate from tritium decay, allowing for a very clean measurement of the energy spectrum. Unlike oscillation experiments, which observe how neutrinos change identity after traveling some distance, KATRIN examines the energy distribution at the moment the neutrino is created. Because these methods probe different aspects of neutrino behavior, they complement each other and together provide strong evidence against the sterile neutrino hypothesis.

How KATRIN Complements Other Experiments

"Our new result is fully complementary to reactor experiments such as STEREO," explains Thierry Lasserre (Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik) in Heidelberg, who led the analysis. "While reactor experiments are most sensitive to sterile-active mass splittings below a few eV2, KATRIN explores the range from a few to several hundred eV². Together, the two approaches now consistently rule out light sterile neutrinos that would noticeably mix with the known neutrino types."

Looking Ahead to More Data and New Detectors

KATRIN will continue collecting data through 2025, which will further improve its sensitivity and allow even stricter tests for light sterile neutrinos. "By the completion of data taking in 2025, KATRIN will have recorded more than 220 million electrons in the region of interest, increasing the statistics by over a factor of six," says KATRIN co-spokesperson Kathrin Valerius (KIT). "This will allow us to push the boundaries of precision and probe mixing angles below the present limits."

An upgrade is planned for 2026, when the TRISTAN detector will be added to the experiment. TRISTAN will record the full tritium β-decay spectrum with unprecedented statistics. By bypassing the main spectrometer and measuring electron energies directly TRISTAN will be able to investigate much heavier sterile neutrinos. "This next-generation setup will open a new window into the keV-mass range, where sterile neutrinos might even form the Universe's dark matter," says co-spokesperson Susanne Mertens (Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik).

An International Scientific Effort

The KATRIN Collaboration brings together scientists from more than 20 institutions across 7 countries, reflecting the global effort behind one of the most precise neutrino experiments ever built.

This has broad implications for physics and cosmology, including dark matter research, and involves a large international collaboration with plans for further upgrades and data collection.
articles.personality_title: KATRIN experiment narrows the search for mysterious sterile neutrinos
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Neutrinos are tiny particles that are very hard to detect but are very common in the Universe. Scientists know about three types of neutrinos, but some experiments suggested there might be a fourth type called a sterile neutrino. Finding this new particle would change what we know about physics.

**What happened**
The KATRIN experiment in Germany studied the decay of tritium, a radioactive form of hydrogen, from 2019 to 2021. It measured the energy of electrons released to look for signs of the sterile neutrino. After analyzing about 36 million electrons, KATRIN found no evidence of this fourth neutrino type, contradicting earlier claims from other experiments.

**Impact**
This result is important because it rules out many possible ways the sterile neutrino could exist, helping scientists focus their research. KATRIN’s precise measurements give a clearer picture of neutrinos and show that some past hints of sterile neutrinos were likely incorrect. It also works alongside other experiments to provide stronger evidence about neutrinos.

**What's next step**
KATRIN will keep collecting more data until 2025, increasing its measurements by six times to search even more carefully. In 2026, a new detector called TRISTAN will be added to study heavier sterile neutrinos, which might help scientists understand dark matter, the mysterious substance making up much of the Universe.

**One-sentence takeaway**
The KATRIN experiment has improved our understanding of neutrinos by ruling out many possibilities for sterile neutrinos and will continue searching with better tools and more data.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'expérience KATRIN resserre la recherche des neutrinos stériles mystérieux
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les neutrinos sont de minuscules particules très difficiles à détecter, mais elles sont très nombreuses dans l'Univers. Les scientifiques connaissent trois types de neutrinos, mais certaines expériences ont suggéré l'existence d'un quatrième type appelé neutrino stérile. Trouver cette nouvelle particule changerait notre compréhension de la physique.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
L'expérience KATRIN en Allemagne a étudié la désintégration du tritium, une forme radioactive d'hydrogène, entre 2019 et 2021. Elle a mesuré l'énergie des électrons émis pour chercher des signes du neutrino stérile. Après avoir analysé environ 36 millions d'électrons, KATRIN n'a trouvé aucune preuve de ce quatrième type de neutrino, contredisant des résultats antérieurs.

**Impact**
Ce résultat est important car il exclut de nombreuses possibilités d'existence du neutrino stérile, aidant les scientifiques à mieux orienter leurs recherches. Les mesures précises de KATRIN clarifient la compréhension des neutrinos et montrent que certains indices passés étaient probablement erronés. L'expérience complète aussi d'autres études pour renforcer les preuves sur les neutrinos.

**Prochaine étape**
KATRIN continuera à collecter des données jusqu'en 2025, multipliant par six ses mesures pour approfondir la recherche. En 2026, un nouveau détecteur nommé TRISTAN sera ajouté pour étudier des neutrinos stériles plus lourds, ce qui pourrait aider à comprendre la matière noire, cette substance mystérieuse qui compose une grande partie de l'Univers.

**Résumé en une phrase**
L'expérience KATRIN a amélioré notre connaissance des neutrinos en excluant de nombreuses possibilités pour les neutrinos stériles et continuera ses recherches avec de meilleurs outils et plus de données.
articles.personality_title_es: El experimento KATRIN reduce la búsqueda de los misteriosos neutrinos estériles
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los neutrinos son partículas muy pequeñas y difíciles de detectar, pero son muy comunes en el Universo. Los científicos conocen tres tipos de neutrinos, pero algunos experimentos sugirieron que podría existir un cuarto tipo llamado neutrino estéril. Encontrar esta nueva partícula cambiaría lo que sabemos sobre la física.

**Qué pasó**
El experimento KATRIN en Alemania estudió la desintegración del tritio, una forma radioactiva de hidrógeno, desde 2019 hasta 2021. Midió la energía de los electrones liberados para buscar señales del neutrino estéril. Después de analizar unos 36 millones de electrones, KATRIN no encontró evidencia de este cuarto tipo de neutrino, contradiciendo reclamos anteriores.

**Impacto**
Este resultado es importante porque descarta muchas de las formas en que podría existir el neutrino estéril, ayudando a los científicos a enfocar mejor su investigación. Las mediciones precisas de KATRIN dan una imagen más clara de los neutrinos y muestran que algunas pistas anteriores probablemente fueron incorrectas. Además, trabaja junto con otros experimentos para dar pruebas más fuertes sobre los neutrinos.

**Próximo paso**
KATRIN seguirá recolectando más datos hasta 2025, aumentando sus mediciones seis veces para buscar con mayor precisión. En 2026, se añadirá un nuevo detector llamado TRISTAN para estudiar neutrinos estériles más pesados, lo que podría ayudar a entender la materia oscura, la misteriosa sustancia que compone gran parte del Universo.

**Resumen en una frase**
El experimento KATRIN ha mejorado nuestra comprensión de los neutrinos al descartar muchas posibilidades para los neutrinos estériles y continuará la búsqueda con mejores herramientas y más datos.
